While the compositions and methods of this invention have been described in terms of preferred embodiments, it will be apparent to those of skill in the art that variations may be applied to the compositions and methods and in the steps or in the sequence of steps of the method described herein without departing from the concept, spirit and scope of the invention. More specifically, it will be apparent that certain agents which are both chemically and physiologically related may be substituted for the agents described herein while the same or similar results would be achieved. All such similar substitutes and modifications apparent to those skilled in the art are deemed to be within the spirit, scope and concept of the invention as defined by the appended claims.

claim.claim-text: 1. An isolated Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide comprising one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, wherein the polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1δ-endotoxin polypeptide.

2. The polypeptide of claim 1, wherein amino acid Lys219 of the polypeptide is substituted by an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue.
3. The polypeptide of claim 2, wherein amino acid Lys219 of the polypeptide is substituted by an alanine, leucine, methionine, glycine or aspartic acid residue.
4. The polypeptide of claim 2, wherein amino acid Lys219 of the polypeptide is substituted by an alanine residue.
5. The polypeptide of claim 1, wherein the polypeptide comprises SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
6. The polypeptide of claim 1, wherein the polypeptide is encoded by SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.

7. A composition comprising a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide, wherein the polypeptide comprises one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, and the polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide.

8. The composition of claim 7, wherein amino acid Lys219 is substituted by an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue.
9. The composition of claim 8, wherein amino acid Lys219 is substituted by an alanine, leucine, methionine, glycine or aspartic acid residue.
10. The composition of claim 8, wherein amino acid Lys219 is substituted by an alanine residue.
11. The composition of claim 7, wherein said polypeptide comprises SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
12. The composition of claim 7, wherein the polypeptide is encoded by SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.

13. The composition of claim 7, wherein the composition comprises a cell extract, cell suspension, cell homogenate, cell lysate, cell supernatant, cell filtrate, or cell pellet from a culture of Bacillus thuringiensis EG12111 or EG12121 cells.
14. The composition of claim 7, wherein the composition is a powder, dust, pellet, granule, spray, emulsion, colloid, or solution.

15. A method of preparing a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide, comprising the steps of:(a) culturing Bacillus thuringiensis EG12111 or EG12121 cells under conditions effective to produce a Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide; and(b) obtaining the Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide so produced.
16. The method of claim 15, wherein the polypeptide comprises SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.

17. An isolated nucleic acid segment encoding a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide, wherein the polypeptide comprises one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, and the polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide.

18. The nucleic acid segment of claim 17, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue for amino acid Lys219.
19. The nucleic acid segment of claim 17, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
20. The isolated nucleic acid segment of claim 17, wherein the nucleic acid segment comprises SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.

21. A nucleic acid vector comprising operably linked in the 5' to 3' direction:a promoter which directs transcription of a nucleic acid segment;a nucleic acid segment encoding a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide wherein:the polypeptide comprises one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, andthe polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide;a 3' transcriptional termination signal; anda 3' polyadenylation signal.

22. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue for amino acid Lys219.
23. The nucleic acid vector of claim 22, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes an alanine residue for amino acid Lys219 in the loop region of the polypeptide.
24. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes a polypeptide comprising SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
25. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the nucleic acid segment comprises SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.
26. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the vector is plasmid, cosmid, phagemid, or artificial chromosome.
27. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the promoter is a heterologous promoter.
28. The nucleic acid vector of claim 21, wherein the promoter is a plant-expressible promoter.

29. The nucleic acid vector of claim 28, wherein the plant-expressible promoter is selected from the group consisting of corn sucrose synthetase 1, corn alcohol dehydrogenase 1, corn light harvesting complex, corn heat shock protein, pea small subunit RuBP carboxylase, Ti plasmid mannopine synthase, Ti plasmid nopaline synthase, petunia chalcone isomerase, bean glycine rich protein 1, Potato patatin, lectin, CaMV 35S, and S-E9 small subunit RuBP carboxylase promoters.

30. A host cell comprising operably linked in the 5' to 3' direction:a promoter which directs transcription of a nucleic acid segment;a nucleic acid segment encoding a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide wherein:the polypeptide comprises one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, andthe polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide;a 3' transcriptional termination signal; anda 3' polyadenylation signal.
31. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the host cell is a prokaryotic, eukaryotic, bacterial, or plant cell.
32. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the host cell is an E. coli, Bacillus thuringiensis, Bacillus subtilis, Bacillus megaterium, Bacillus cereus, or Pseudomonas spp. cell.
33. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the host cell is a Bacillus thuringiensis EG121111 or EG12121 cell.

34. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the host cell is a corn, wheat, soybean, oat, cotton, rice, barley, turf grass, pasture grass, berry, fruit, legume, vegetable, ornamental plant, shrub, or tree cell.
35. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
36. The host cell of claim 30, wherein the nucleic acid segment is SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.

37. A transgenic plant comprising operably linked in the 5' to 3' direction:a promoter which directs transcription of a nucleic acid segment;a nucleic acid segment encoding a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide wherein:the polypeptide comprises one or more amino acid mutations in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1, andthe polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide;a 3' transcriptional termination signal; anda 3' polyadenylation signal.

38. The transgenic plant of claim 37, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue for amino acid Lys219.
39. The transgenic plant of claim 38, wherein amino acid Lys219 is substituted by an alanine, leucine, methionine, glycine or aspartic acid residue.
40. The transgenic plant of claim 38, wherein amino acid Lys219 is substituted by an alanine residue.
41. The transgenic plant of claim 37, wherein the nucleic acid segment encodes a polypeptide comprising SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
42. The transgenic plant of claim 37, wherein the nucleic acid segment comprises SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.
43. The transgenic plant of claim 37, further defined as a monocotyledonous plant.
44. The transgenic plant of claim 43, further defined as a corn, wheat, oat, rice, barley, turf grass, or pasture grass plant.
45. The transgenic plant of claim 37, further defined as a dicotyledonous plant.
46. The transgenic plant of claim 45, further defined as a legume, soybean, cotton, fruit, berry, or tree.

47. A method of controlling Lepidopteran insects comprising contacting said insects with an insecticidally-effective amount of a Bacillus thuringienis Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide, wherein:the polypeptide comprises at least one amino acid mutation in the loop region between α helices 6 and 7 of domain 1; andthe polypeptide has improved insecticidal activity against Lepidopteran insects relative to a native Cry1C δ-endotoxin polypeptide.

48. The method of claim 47, wherein amino acid Lys219 of the polypeptide is substituted by an alanine, arginine, asparagine, aspartic acid, cysteine, glutamic acid, glutamine, glycine, histidine, isoleucine, leucine, methionine, phenylalanine, proline, serine, threonine, tryptophan, tyrosine, or valine residue.
49. The method of claim 47, wherein the polypeptide comprises SEQ ID NO:59 or SEQ ID NO:61.
50. The method of claim 47, wherein the polypeptide is encoded by SEQ ID NO:58 or SEQ ID NO:60.
